field_edited_text.value:
" ol





ike scattering seeds, the colonial



legislatures of Maryland and Virginia
= planted hundreds of towns along the
shores of the Chesapeake Bay. Many, like
London Town and Joppa, have disappeared
with little or no trace. Others have
survived as fishing villages, yacht havens or
historic attractions such as Yorktown and
Port Tobacco. A few are busy as county
seats, and Richmond and Annapolis are
the state capitals, but only one of them—
Baltimore—became a commercial and
industrial metropolis ranking among the
top twenty in the nation. Baltimore’s port
was the difference.



7l

The story begins with a 1729 act of the
Maryland legislature authorizing commis-
sioners to survey and lay out a town on
“the north side of Patapsco River” to be
called Baltimore. In January 1730 the
commissioners and their surveyor, Philip
Jones, chose the head of the Northwest
Branch for the town site. They started the
survey at the water’s edge from a “bounded
red oak” at what is now the site of the
U.S.F. &G. skyscraper, and traced an
irregular sixfy acre tract which would
include today most of Charles Center, the
financial district, the Court House, City
Hall, and the Custom House. The edge of
the harbor at that time can be partly
traced in the irregular line of Water and
Lombard Streets.

As it proved, the location of Baltimore
Town was superb for the development of a
seagoing commerce in wheat, flour, and
preserved meats and fish. The original har-
bor, once called the “Basin” and now the
Inner Harbor, was well protected by hills
on the north and south. Two streams,
Jones Falls and Gwynn’s Falls, had the
potential to drive water-powered grist
mills, and a few miles away the Patapsco
River offered much more power. The
source of the raw materials for trade was
in the higher land to the north and west,
the fertile valleys of the Piedmont Plateau
stretching up into Pennsylvania and west
to the Appalachian mountains. This coun-
try was excellent for grass crops, both for
pasture and grains, and it was heavily
wooded with oak.
